The sun behind proud Merrion's towers,</br>Calls off his ardent conq'ring powers.</br>Reluctant light slow quits the plain,</br>And yields to sable Night's domain.</br>The op'ning rose-bud hangs its head,</br>The tulip droops upon her bed;</br>And mourns until the morning ray,</br>Shall bid her all her charms display.</br>That ray, which now scarce paints the grove,</br>And gives the parting kiss of love;</br>To Howth's tall hill, whose blushing face</br>Receives Sol's lingering last embrace;</br>'Tis darkness all!  but soon we'll see,</br>The Moon in splendid majesty.

And lo!  she comes, with decent pride,</br>Moving thro' th' ethereal tide;</br>Stars resplendent join her train,</br>Hail her Queen, and grace her reign.</br>View'd from Irishtown's sweet shore,</br>Dublin Bay looks silver'd o'er,</br>Whilst in wat'ry murmurs faint,</br>Spirits make their sad complaint,</br>That no tender friend was by,</br>To receive their parting sigh;</br>Nor to shed the silent tear,</br>O'er the flow'r-bestrewed bier.</br>Howth emerging from the deep,</br>Shews its awful rocky steep:</br>Points to Charlemont's fair dome,</br>Patriotic virtues home.</br>Softest scenes my eye arrest,</br>Sweet sensations fill my breast.</br>'Till with black frowns Ringsend steals in,</br>And like unhappy Adam's sin</br>Saddens the view, and in a thrice</br>To Hell itself sinks Paradise;</br>While from that side the sailors' cry</br>Proclaims the crowded shipping nigh.

Hark the sprightly violin</br>Tells the moon-light sports begin!</br>Let us to the green repair,</br>Mirth and Music's voice I hear.</br>Where the church its gothic head,</br>Lifts among the peaceful dead.</br>Dismal bells toll out no more,</br>Dinning with their plaints the shore.</br>Death in vain is monarch here,</br>Youthful Frolick knows no fear,</br>All his threats we set at nought,</br>On him let's not lose a thought!</br>Come — the country dance lead down,</br>'Tis the life of Irishtown.

Where the mossy banks permit,</br>Eager-looking matrons sit;</br>Whilst their daughters young and gay,</br>Trip it merrily away.</br>Extasy marks every face,</br>Innocence and lively grace.</br>Who can view and not be charm'd?</br>Drooping Age itself is warm'd,</br>When to music's lively sound,</br>Feet unnumber'd press the ground,</br>Rage, and Strife, and Vice away!</br>Innocence is not your prey:</br>Curs'd be the Deluder's art,</br>That could wound one virtuous heart.

Gods!  what gigling, sporting, swearing!</br>I'm afraid t'will hurt my hearing;</br>Beaux unnumber'd group'd together,</br>Light and sportive as a feather,</br>Zealous to display perfections,</br>Move about in all directions;</br>Youth and beauty disappear,</br>Quick as thought — the coast is clear.</br>Now bucks advance — your cares are o'er,</br>You've swept the counter, shut the door;</br>Your angry masters' gone to bed,</br>This night, no blows you'll have to dread.</br>Each here appears as an Adonis,</br>So snug his face, so neat each bone is;</br>Assur'd of this, your dear selves proffer,</br>As partners — who'll refuse the offer?</br>For Ladies like that you should treat 'em,</br>To what you have — some musk'd pomatum.

Hear the bagpipes zerking note!</br>Mark each zigging petticoat!</br>Whilst the squeak of ill-tim'd flutes,</br>Thro' my pericranium shoots;</br>Hopping, squeezing, ogling, nodding:</br>Sideways, frontways, glances flying,</br>Belles exulting, Gallants dying.

Retrograde with many a thump,</br>Yonder Damsel smacks her rump</br>'Gainst her heedless paramour,</br>Down he falls on Earth's hard floor—</br>Take him up, and bear him hence,</br>This may teach him to have sense!</br>Hair dishevell'd!  waistcoat burst!</br>Irishtown and Pipes be curs'd.</br>Noise succeeds, and sad confusion,</br>At a brother Fop's contusion;</br>All the conquering rump askance,</br>Eye, with fear, and quit the dance.
CONCLUSION.</br>In slow numbers, soft and sweet,</br>Bagpipes celebrate the fete;</br>Let the conquering Maid be crown'd,</br>And her rump with laurels bound.

Now the fiddle of recall,</br>Bids them vacate the church wall.</br>Dublin, Dublin, is the cry—</br>Dublin echoes thro' the sky:</br>Straight embody'd Beaux depart,</br>Carrying each, a fair-one's heart;</br>Boasting, loudly, without measure,</br>Of the captive, lovely treasure,</br>Taken by the force of locks,</br>Charg'd with powder, and fierce cocks!</br>Should a drunken Sailor dare</br>To impede their proud career,</br>Fierce, impetuous, ten to one,</br>Soon they make the foe begone;</br>Or, with many a kick and pound,</br>Trail his sides along the ground.

Go noble youths — and still may Fame</br>Prolong your virtues and your name;</br>May Irishtown, still own your merit,</br>And every Police-house your spirit!</br>But deign your scouts to call away,</br>Who, thro' our streets, each morning stray,</br>Yelping their execrable oaths,</br>And straining, puppy-like, their throats—</br>Oh!  take them with you, they're your own,</br>And leave to peace, and sleep, this town.</br>
